greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = gcd(Product_{p|n} (p+1)^b(p,n), Product_{p|n} (p-1)^b(p,n)), where the products are over the distinct primes, p, that divide n and p^b(p,n) is the highest power of p dividing n.
comment: First occurrence of k or 0 if not possible (including all odd primes k): 2, 1, 0, 9, 0, 14, 0, 15, 0, 0, 0, 42, 0, 0, 0, 45, 0, 76, 0, 589, 0, 0, 0, 35, 0, 0, 0, 4381, 0, 0, ..., . - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 08 2007
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..12441
Antti Karttunen, Data supplement: n, a(n) computed for n = 1..100000
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{fi = FactorInteger@n}, GCD[Times @@ ((First /@ fi - 1)^Last /@ fi), Times @@ ((First /@ fi + 1)^Last /@ fi)]]; Array[f, 99] - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 08 2007
program: A003958(n) = { my(f = factor(n)); for(i=1, #f~, f[i, 1]--); factorback(f); };
A003959(n) = { my(f = factor(n)); for(i=1, #f~, f[i, 1]++); factorback(f); };
